docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton proposed today to spend nearly $25 billion over the next decade on reducing class sizes in elementary schools, building and renovating schools and addressing a variety of other problems in the nation's education system. White House officials said the proposals would be highlighted by Mr. Clinton in his State of the Union Message on Tuesday night, along with a host of other policy initiatives the Administration has outlined in recent weeks. Those include expanding health insurance coverage for early retirees, addressing the looming problems in Social Security and increasing spending on food safety and inspection.

headline.main: Clinton Proposes Spending $25 Billion on Education
headline.kicker: THE PRESIDENT UNDER FIRE: THE MESSAGE

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton proposes spending nearly $25 billion over next decade on reducing class sizes in elementary schools, building and renovating schools and addressing variety of other problems in nation's education system; proposals will be highlighted in State of the Union address (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AT 6:15 A.M. Catherine Donahue is still sleepy as she begins her workday. She opens the door of her ranch-style house in New Haven and greets Ryan Ferraiolo, 7, and Page Ferraiolo, 5 years old. She feeds them breakfast and puts them on their school bus. Mrs. Donahue, a day care provider, agreed to wake up early for the the two youngsters whose mother, Patricia Ferraiolo, must be at her hospital job by 6:30 A.M. But when other mothers asked Mrs. Donahue to work later to accommodate their night jobs, she refused. ''I have to take care of my own kids,'' said the mother of four. In the next two years, there will be at least 27,000 more children in the state needing day care because welfare laws now require recipients to go to work after 21 months on welfare, according to the Connecticut Commission on Children.

headline.main: Changes in Welfare Push Demand for Child Care

docs.abstract: Connecticut Commission on Children says in next two years, there will be at least 27,000 more children in state needing day care because welfare laws now require recipients to go to work after 21 months; child advocates say day care in Connecticut is inadequate, and increased need resulting from welfare reform exacerbates problem; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: On the day he was to have what he would later call his ''meeting with the devil,'' Randy Warren woke up early. It was the last day of April 1997, and Warren had spent a restless night in a hotel at the Toronto airport, two hours from his home, awaiting the morning arrival of two strangers, businessmen from New Jersey. The strangers were executives of the Celgene Corporation, a tiny pharmaceutical company that is seeking Government approval to market thalidomide, the world's most notorious agent of birth defects. Warren, the founder and chief executive officer of the Thalidomide Victims Association of Canada, had come to provide these men with living proof of their product's ruinous past.
